title.rendered: New Logo and Identity for Chance to Shine by Article

content.rendered:
Established in 2005, Chance to Shine is a UK charity dedicated to reversing the decline in cricket — the sport not the insect — in state schools. It sounds weird, yes. The goal isn’t to get kids to go cricket crazy or find the next Million Dollar Arm but to “bring young people from all walks of life together and teach life skills that will stay with them forever”. They have brought cricket — by training teachers, providing equipment, linking schools to local cricket clubs — to 2.5 million children in 11,000 state schools across England and Wales. Recently, Chance to Shine introduced a new identity designed by London-based Article.

[The logo] is based on the combination of a batsman’s wagon wheel graphic and a spark. The spark comes from the ‘shine’ part of the charity’s name and represents the positive benefits it ignites in young people like teamwork, passion, discipline and respect. The reach and impact of our programmes is encapsulated in a new strapline: ‘spreading the power of cricket’.

Chance to Shine press release

Based on the combination of a batsman’s wagon wheel and a spark, the simple yellow lines of the ‘Spark’ logo are used dynamically throughout the identity in print, digital and moving image, visually representing Chance to Shine’s ambition to spread the power of cricket far and wide.

Article provided text

It’s amazing that Chance to Shine got a single kid to pick up a bat with that near-parody of a logo they had: a stitched apple (like a cricket ball) with a poor man’s Comic Sans wordmark and a Lithos tagline. More power to them. The new logo takes the visual of the wagon wheel — “A graphical chart which divides a cricket ground into six sectors and shows how many runs a batsman has scored into each area” (as described by Wikipedia) — and turns it into a spark. As an idea, it’s a nice blend of the charity’s main focus and its name; and, as an icon, it’s a simple, energetic identifier. It works best against black, looking like an exploding firework. The typography is fairly forgettable and not quite well related to the icon; it’s neither bolder enough to be clearly distinct nor is it light enough to match the thickness of the spark. The uppercase approach makes it too serious as well.

In application, there is a lot of yellow and black, a lot of different diagonals that play off the icon and the introduction of a stencil font (that doesn’t feel like a natural fit). It’s all pretty decent if a little hodgepodge at times. Nonetheless, I am sure it’s a vast improvement over whatever materials they previously had and the new identity establishes a more clear and engaging visual link between the organization and cricket.
